comments:
This course covers many of the radical poetry movements and individual innovations, along with the more conventional and idiosyncratic work. It provides examples of political, social, ethnic, and national poetries, both in the Americas and Europe, and beyond to the rest of the world. This course asks: what happens to the lyric poem in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries? Readings may include: Swinburne’s decadent ballads, H.D.’s crystalline feminist myths, Mina Loy’s cerebral love songs, Lorine Niedecker’s “cremated haiku.”

Overall students enjoyed the readings offered in Professor Bloch’s course and appreciated her ability to integrate a number of topics. Though the class was small and discussion based, some students wished there had been more active participation while others wished Bloch had shared her own opinions more often.

Students appreciated Professor Bloch’s “connection to modern poets” as well as her forward-thinking use of blogging and twitter to allow students to share with each other. Professor Bloch is described as an “immensely passionate and intelligent” person as well as a “very fair” teacher.

Both majors and non-majors enrolled in this course. One student remarked that meeting with Professor Bloch was helpful. Assessments included a midterm and final exam, as well as two five-page essays and regular responses to course materials using a collaborative blog and Twitter feed. Based on fewer than 8 comments.
